snippet.textDisplay: Ok, so RE: it's weird that computers work at all. With ultra-high-frequency electronics (like in a computer) the time it takes a signal to travel down a trace on the PCB becomes significant. When there's a parallel bus (such as the address or data busses) consisting of several traces that each carry a single bit of the whole word, because those bits are all associated with each other they have to arrive at the same time (so the receiver knows they're all part of the same thing). The problem is that any time you have to make a bend on the PCB, the trace on the outside of the bend must take a longer path than the trace on the inside. The designers of the boards, therefore, have to design in bits of the trace to extend those traces that took shorter paths. So you'll often see little wiggle patterns in some traces to make sure that pulses of electricity arrive at the exact same time to the nanosecond.
snippet.textOriginal: Ok, so RE: it's weird that computers work at all. With ultra-high-frequency electronics (like in a computer) the time it takes a signal to travel down a trace on the PCB becomes significant. When there's a parallel bus (such as the address or data busses) consisting of several traces that each carry a single bit of the whole word, because those bits are all associated with each other they have to arrive at the same time (so the receiver knows they're all part of the same thing). The problem is that any time you have to make a bend on the PCB, the trace on the outside of the bend must take a longer path than the trace on the inside. The designers of the boards, therefore, have to design in bits of the trace to extend those traces that took shorter paths. So you'll often see little wiggle patterns in some traces to make sure that pulses of electricity arrive at the exact same time to the nanosecond.

snippet.textDisplay:
3:30 This is something that's interested me for a while. As in, why'd software bottleneck hardware (my favourite example, which has been explained to me, is why AoE takes so long to install on systems decades younger than the game itself).

Also, isn't 40Gb = 5 GB?

snippet.textDisplay:
What if you used ZFS!?
Oh wait, you actually did. Did you use Unix?! Or did you alienate zfs...
I tried 1Mbyte read s on Solaris ZFS Enterprise server (size of a walk in fridge) and talked to engineers why it didn't work. They replied "you don't have an application that can read 1 Mbyte per io, you first have to write that as it does not exist at this moment" and that was actually true. It is in the software not to do that.
snippet.textOriginal:
What if you used ZFS!?
Oh wait, you actually did. Did you use Unix?! Or did you alienate zfs...
I tried 1Mbyte read s on Solaris ZFS Enterprise server (size of a walk in fridge) and talked to engineers why it didn't work. They replied "you don't have an application that can read 1 Mbyte per io, you first have to write that as it does not exist at this moment" and that was actually true.  It is in the software not to do that.

snippet.textDisplay:
We had similar problems with SATA3. Our SSDs were so fast, they regularly tripped and effed the controller. We are of course working with a smaller scale of hardware here, less expensive stuff, so we don't have the scale to go full NVME servers... But the same problem does exist in lower scales... We happen to limit the speed on our drives too, because we don't actually need all that speed anyway.


We mostly use SSD tech to not have moving drives that fall apart lol
snippet.textOriginal:
We had similar problems with SATA3. Our SSDs were so fast, they regularly tripped and effed the controller. We are of course working with a smaller scale of hardware here, less expensive stuff, so we don't have the scale to go full NVME servers... But the same problem does exist in lower scales... We happen to limit the speed on our drives too, because we don't actually need all that speed anyway.


We mostly use SSD tech to not have moving drives that fall apart lol

snippet.textDisplay: Interesting topic.  I wonder if Wendell's solution is the same thing as hybrid polling in Linux.  In hybrid polling, after an I/O request is sent to a drive, the kernel sets a timer for half as long as it thinks the request will take, and when that timer expires it wakes up the process that made the request, so it can begin polling.  This way you eliminate roughly half the CPU overhead of polling, while getting all the performance of polling.
snippet.textOriginal: Interesting topic.  I wonder if Wendell's solution is the same thing as hybrid polling in Linux.  In hybrid polling, after an I/O request is sent to a drive, the kernel sets a timer for half as long as it thinks the request will take, and when that timer expires it wakes up the process that made the request, so it can begin polling.  This way you eliminate roughly half the CPU overhead of polling, while getting all the performance of polling.

snippet.textDisplay: @LinusTechTips I got this discussed with our storage guru, and he says, that for high performance and IOPS, you might want to have a single low machine per drive (like ARM, he mentions Mars 400) connected via 10Gbit LAN, which would be organized in something like CEPH cluster.
snippet.textOriginal: @LinusTechTips I got this discussed with our storage guru, and he says, that for high performance and IOPS, you might want to have a single low machine per drive (like ARM, he mentions Mars 400) connected via 10Gbit LAN, which would be organized in something like CEPH cluster.

snippet.textDisplay: I have always had an elementary question: How to avoid cross-wiring(data corruption my misdirecting data) when random-reading, particularly without fewer safety mechanisms, which, granted, bloat the setup?  Also, this sounds inspired by RAID 1 almost, nevermind the dragging 0, from how you present this.  Furthermore, what processors are you implementing?  The processor chiplets, and the singularity of parts are integral to something aimed at quality, not being able to just see the next minute.  There remains also the question of how deep the processors allot caching, as it in this case seems a volatile argument for either side.  I wonder about what levels of saturation of chips become an oversaturation, as this now sounds a drought.  Each NVMe comes with its own card(s), and there is the curiosity about addressing the MFTs.  For the, note, PERSONAL, system(s) I had, I noted, with my doing multiple things simultaneously, a, not removal, but minimization of paging, greatly sped it.  If you guys are employing VMs, that would bring another barrier and filter.  The question is further exascerbated by the hookup systems and their limitations.  To be an asshole, I will even query Plasma as display, which I would be VERY surprised if you had not already countered into.  Perhaps it would be best to remove all sensors, considering the inherent I/O delays and the system trying to match.  I only see ONE facet, thus pose these queries.  And you DID say unbuffered RAM, yes?
snippet.textOriginal: I have always had an elementary question: How to avoid cross-wiring(data corruption my misdirecting data) when random-reading, particularly without fewer safety mechanisms, which, granted, bloat the setup?  Also, this sounds inspired by RAID 1 almost, nevermind the dragging 0, from how you present this.  Furthermore, what processors are you implementing?  The processor chiplets, and the singularity of parts are integral to something aimed at quality, not being able to just see the next minute.  There remains also the question of how deep the processors allot caching, as it in this case seems a volatile argument for either side.  I wonder about what levels of saturation of chips become an oversaturation, as this now sounds a drought.  Each NVMe comes with its own card(s), and there is the curiosity about addressing the MFTs. snippet.textDisplay:
Ok, this is a bad idea, but think about this:
1. Use the 64 core CPU but artificially block 24 cores from CPU scheduler by use of the kernel. Then, run some tightly written assembler on each of them which polls memory for a new "command" at a specific address, which says whether to read or write, the address to read from/write to and the destination/source memory address. If one is read, do what it says (with polling, the CPU core has literally nothing else to do), writing/reading to/from the memory address specified and delete it.
2. Write a device driver that interfaces with this CPU-based device proxy and make the device available in /dev like any other drive.
3. You now have 24 high-speed devices to make an array on. Do whatever you want with them.

Tell me what in my plan is wrong. I'm open to being corrected.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ok, this is a bad idea, but think about this:
1. Use the 64 core CPU but artificially block 24 cores from CPU scheduler by use of the kernel. Then, run some tightly written assembler on each of them which polls memory for a new "command" at a specific address, which says whether to read or write, the address to read from/write to and the destination/source memory address. If one is read, do what it says (with polling, the CPU core has literally nothing else to do), writing/reading to/from the memory address specified and delete it.
2. Write a device driver that interfaces with this CPU-based device proxy and make the device available in /dev like any other drive.
3. You now have 24 high-speed devices to make an array on. Do whatever you want with them.

Tell me what in my plan is wrong. I'm open to being corrected.
